Detailed Description

An extension to the normal VRTEventListener that supports additional handling for context packets.

The use of receivedDataPacket, receivedContextPacket, and/or receivedInitialContext are mutually exclusive with receivedPacket.

Note that it is an error to call receivedInitialContext more than once (without a "reset") or to call receivedDataPacket or receivedContextPacket before the call to receivedInitialContext.

Prior to Oct 2013 this erroneously called out uses of BasicContextPacket (i.e. an IF Context Packet) in situations where use of extension context packets were also legal (per documentation and per ANSI/VITA-49.0). Accordingly the interface was forced to change as follows: 

    Old Version:
      receivedContextPacket(VRTEvent,BasicContextPacket)
      receivedInitialContext(VRTEvent,String,BasicDataPacket,BasicContextPacket,
                             map<int32_t,BasicContextPacket>)
    New Version:
      receivedContextPacket(VRTEvent,BasicVRTPacket)
      receivedInitialContext(VRTEvent,String,BasicDataPacket,BasicVRTPacket,
                             map<int32_t,BasicVRTPacket>)
    Note that the constructors also had to change as a result.

Traditional C-style callback constructor.

This is similar in concept to the C signal(..) which function takes pointers to the applicable functions to call.

virtual void vrt::VRTContextListener::receivedInitialContext ( const VRTEvent &  e,
const string &  errorMsg,
const BasicDataPacket &  data,
const BasicVRTPacket &  ctx,
const map< int32_t, BasicVRTPacket > &  context 
) [virtual]

This method is called when the initial set of VRT context packets have been received.

Note that calling this function with a non-null errorMsg (as detailed below) is a substitute for calling errorOccurred where it directly relates to the initial context.

Parameters:
e The event object.
errorMsg Did an error occur while trying to get the initial context? This will be set to the empty string ("") if there were no errors and the attendant information is believed to be correct. This will return NO_CONTEXT_STREAM or NO_DATA_STREAM in the event of a timeout where there was data without context or context without data -- both of these are valid under the VITA-49 standard, but often discouraged as they present an ambiguous situation where it is impossible to tell what the primary context should be (i.e. ctx will be null and data and context may be incomplete).

Note: The NO_CONTEXT_STREAM and NO_DATA_STREAM will not be used in situations where external information is available that identifies the primary context stream or the lack there of. In this situation there is no ambiguity and the attendant information is believed to be correct.

The way the "timeout" is implemented, it results in a call to this function at the time the first packet is received following the timeout -- as such it is impossible to have a situation where this function is called and no packets (data or context) have been received.

A summary of the special cases: 

                           Error       |   Found     |    Found Any    | Found Primary  |
                          Message      | Data Stream | Context Streams | Context Stream |
                    -------------------+-------------+-----------------+----------------+
                    NO_CONTEXT_STREAM  |     Yes     |       No        |       No       |
                    -------------------+-------------+-----------------+----------------+
                    NO_DATA_STREAM     |     No      |       Yes       |     Unknown    |
                    -------------------+-------------+-----------------+----------------+
                    ""                 |     Yes     |       Yes       |       Yes      |
                    -------------------+-------------+-----------------+----------------+
                    not possible       |     No      |       No        |       No       |
                    -------------------+-------------+-----------------+----------------+

Any other error messages reflect a situation where there has been a clear error (i.e. a violation of the VITA-49 specification) and the attendant information is the "best available" but clearly believed incorrect -- it is however, included as some systems may be able to "recover" from the error and/or provide a meaningful diagnostic message to the user.

data The data packet that was used to identify the primary context. Note that this data packet should be considered "out of band" and should be discarded (i.e. its chronological relationship between ctx and any other packets received is intentionally undefined); it is present only as an indication that there is (or is not) a data stream and its stream identifier. If this data packet is valid to process at this time, a subsequent call to receivedDataPacket will be made.
ctx The primary context packet.
context The context packets received (may be read-only). This will be a mapping of stream identifier to context packet. (This will include ctx.) This map may be empty, but it will never be null. None of the packets included in this map will be included in a subsequent receivedContextPacket call.

Error message passed with receivedInitialContext when no context streams have been found before the timeout expired.

Error message passed with receivedInitialContext when no data stream has been found before the timeout expired.
